issue_name: APT28 Exploits Known Vulnerability to Carry Out Reconnaissance and Deploy Malware on Cisco Routers

1.description: Patch devices as advised by Cisco.

2.description: Do not use SNMP if you are not required to configure or manage devices remotely.

3.command: Establish allow and deny lists for SNMP
3.description: If you are required to manage routers remotely, establish allow and deny lists for SNMP messages.

4.description: Do not allow unencrypted (i.e., plaintext) management protocols, such as SNMP v2 and Telnet.

5.description: Carry out any management activities from outside the organization through an encrypted virtual private network (VPN), where both ends are mutually authenticated.

6.description: Enforce a strong password policy. Don’t reuse the same password for multiple devices. Each device should have a unique password.

7.description: Where possible, avoid legacy password-based authentication and implement two-factor authentication based on public-private key.

8.description: Disable legacy unencrypted protocols such as Telnet and SNMP v1 or v2c.

9.description: Where possible, use modern encrypted protocols such as SSH and SNMP v3.

10.description: Harden the encryption protocols based on current best security practice.

11.description: Retire and replace legacy devices that can’t be configured to use SNMP v3.

12.description: Use logging tools to record commands executed on your network devices, such as TACACS+ and Syslog.

13.description: Use logs to immediately highlight suspicious events and keep a record of events to support an investigation if the device’s integrity is ever in question.

14.description: Follow Cisco’s advice for verifying the Cisco IOS image.

15.description: Revoke all keys associated with the compromised router.

16.description: When replacing the router configuration, create new keys rather than pasting from the old configuration.

17.command: Replace ROMMON and Cisco IOS image
17.description: Replace both the ROMMON and Cisco IOS image with an image sourced directly from the Cisco website.
